ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: DATA=SAS-data-set] 
      
Specifies the input SAS data set to use. If this option is omitted, the most recently 
created SAS data set is used.

[Syntax: EPSILON=number] 
      
Specifies the convergence value of the objective function for METHOD=ML or METHOD=REML. 
By default, EPSILON=1E-8.

[Syntax: MAXITER=number] 
      
Specifies the maximum number of iterations for METHOD=ML or METHOD=REML. 
By default, MAXITER=50.
Specifies which of the five methods (TYPE1, MIVQUE0, ML, REML, or GRR) you want to use.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Applies to any random-effects model and design.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Applies to any random-effects model and design.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Applies to any random-effects model and design.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Applies to any random-effects model and design.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: [Syntax: GRR<(options)>]                                  Provides a specialized analysis only for certain designs.  You can specify the following options in parentheses after METHOD=GRR.     SPECLIMITS=(LSL,USL,<k>)   SL=(LSL,USL,<k>)   specifies the specification limits for the first random factor, which is regarded as the product    being tested in the gauge R and R study.     RATIO    specifies that certain additional ratios of variance components should also be computed and displayed,    such as proportion of total variance due to the process.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: BY <DESCENDING> variable-1 <...<DESCENDING> variable-n> <NOTSORTED>; 
      
You can specify a BY statement with PROC VARCOMP to obtain separate analyses on 
observations in groups that are defined by the BY variables. When a BY statement 
appears, the procedure expects the input data set to be sorted in order of the BY 
variables. If you specify more than one BY statement, only the last one specified 
is used.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies that the observations are sorted in descending order by the variable that 
immediately follows the word DESCENDING in the BY statement.
Specifies that observations are not necessarily sorted in alphabetic or numeric order.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: CLASS variables ;
      
The CLASS statement specifies the classification variables to be used in the analysis. 
All effects in the MODEL statement must be composed of effects that appear in the CLASS 
statement. Classification variables can be either numeric or character; if they are 
character, only the first 16 characters are used. 

Numeric classification variables are not restricted to integers since a variable’s 
format determines the levels.

Syntax: MODEL dependent = <effects> </ options> ;
      
The MODEL statement gives the dependent variables and independent effects. If you 
specify more than one dependent variable, a separate analysis is performed for each 
one. The independent effects are limited to main effects, interactions, and nested 
effects; no continuous effects are allowed. All independent effects must be composed 
of effects that appear in the CLASS statement. Effects are specified in the VARCOMP 
procedure in the same way as described for the ANOVA procedure. Only one MODEL 
statement is allowed.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: FIXED=n] 
          
Specifies that the first n effects in the MODEL statement are fixed effects.

Specifies that confidence limits for all of the parameters of interest should be 
computed and displayed. It also optionally specifies the method to use for 
computing the confidence limits. 

The CL option applies only to balanced one-way or two-way designs for METHOD=TYPE1 or GRR.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies the modified large-sample (MLS) method for computing the confidence limits.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies the generalized confidence limits (GCL) method for computing the confidence limits.                                      You can specify the following options in parentheses after CL=GCL.     NSAMPLE=n    specifies the sample size for generalized pivot quantities (GPQ) sampling. The default    value is 12,605.     EPSILON=number    specifies a small positive value used in some GPQ computations. The default value is 0.001.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: ALPHA=α] 
          
Specifies the level of significance α for (1-α)100% two-sided confidence limits. The value of 
α must be between 0 and 1. By default, α is equal to 0.05.
